revision.comment: Rescued 2 archive links; remove 1 link; reformat 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Use South African English|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = Malegapuru William Makgoba | honorific-suffix = [[Order of Mapungubwe|OMS]] | image = MakgobaHillLecture.jpg | imagesize = | alt = Makgoba delivering the James C. Hill Memorial Lecture at the [[National Institutes of Health|NIH]] Campus in [[Bethesda, Maryland|Bethesda]] in 2001. | caption = Makgoba delivering the James C. Hill Memorial Lecture at the [[National Institutes of Health|NIH]] Campus in [[Bethesda, Maryland|Bethesda]] in 2001. | order = | office = Vice-Chancellor of the [[University of KwaZulu-Natal]] | term_start = 1 January 2004 | term_end = 31 December 2014 | birth_date = 1952 | birth_place = [[Sekhukhune District Municipality|Sekhukhune]], [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]]
[[Union of South Africa]] | nationality = [[South Africa]]n | alma_mater = [[University of Natal]]
[[University of Oxford]] | occupation = | website = {{url|makgoba.ukzn.ac.za}} | footnotes = }} '''Malegapuru William Makgoba''' (born 1952 in [[Sekhukhune District Municipality|Sekhukhune]], [[Union of South Africa|South Africa]]) is a leading [[South Africa]]n [[immunology|immunologist]], [[physician]], public health advocate, academic and former [[Chancellor (education)|vice-chancellor]] of the [[University of KwaZulu-Natal]]. In 2013 he was recognised as "a pioneer in higher education transformation",{{cite news |title=Media statement by the Chancellor of the National Orders, Dr Cassius Lubisi |url=http://www.info.gov.za/speech/DynamicAction?pageid=461&sid=35913&tid=105146 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218132609/http://www.info.gov.za/speech/DynamicAction?pageid=461&sid=35913&tid=105146 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-12-18 }} by being awarded the [[Order of Mapungubwe]] in Silver, but has also generated extensive controversy during that process. ==Academic career== Makgoba received an [[Bachelor of Medicine and Surgery|MBChB]] degree from the [[University of KwaZulu-Natal|University of Natal Medical School]] in 1976 with merit in medicine. In 1979 he was named the first black Nuffield Dominion Fellow to the [[University of Oxford]],{{cite news |title=A benefaction and its benefits. The Oxford Nuffield Medical Fellowship and South Africa|author=Collin Bundy|url=http://www.samj.org.za/index.php/samj/issue/view/113 |newspaper=South African Medical Journal volume 101|date= July 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2012}} where he completed his [[Doctor of Philosophy#United Kingdom|DPhil]] degree in human immunogenetics from in 1983 under [[Andrew James McMichael|Professor Sir Andrew McMichael]].{{cite press release |title=Professor Malegapuru William Makgoba – University of KwaZulu-Natal |url=http://nrfcoms.info/NRFPressroom/?p=314 |publisher=[[National Research Foundation of South Africa]] |date=21 September 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2012 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The title of his thesis was "Studies on the polymorphism of HLA class II antigens". He went on to become the first senior registrar to fellow expatriate South African and President of Royal College of Physicians of London, Sir [[Raymond Hoffenberg]], in 1983. He was Reader in Molecular Endocrinology at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School London (1990–94) He was the first black South African to be selected to the prestigious [[National Institute of Health]]'s Fogarty Visiting Programme in the late 1980s. Makgoba was appointed the first black deputy vice-chancellor at the [[University of the Witwatersrand]] in 1995.{{cite news |title=To Wit: a culture clash |author=Karen MacGregor |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=92445§ioncode=26 |newspaper=Times Higher Education |date=9 February 1996 |accessdate=2 February 2012}} Makgoba left Wits University to join the [[South African Medical Research Council]]. He was appointed the first black Chairperson of the MRC Board(1995-1998). He thereafter served as President of the South African Medical Research Council between 1999 and 2002 and was involved in developing South Africa's AIDS strategy and the SA AIDS Vaccine Initiative. Professor Makgoba joined the former [[University of Natal]] as its Vice-Chancellor in 2002, and oversaw its merger with the [[University of Durban-Westville]] into the [[University of KwaZulu-Natal]]. UKZN is one of the top five research-intensive universities in the country{{cite journal|last=Kahn|first=M|title=Setting the Scene: The NSI Measurement and Steering at the NACI workshop on Measuring the System of Innovation|journal=NACI workshop|date=24–25 April 2006}} and ranked amongst the top 500 Universities in the World.{{cite news |title=UKZN ranks among top 500 universities in the world |author=Mercury reporter |url=http://www.gate5.co.za/qv/pr/14060235/16713034/9221/p |newspaper=MERCURY |date=19 August 1996 |accessdate=6 February 2012}}{{cite web|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities|url=http://www.arwu.org/|publisher=ARWU|accessdate=9 February 2012}} During 2007-2008, the university raised 577 million [[South African rand]]s (about 57 million Euros) in total research funding.{{cite news |title=Hi-tech facility to aid TB, HIV research|url=http://www.gate5.co.za/qv/pr/13724863/16418643/9221/t |newspaper=Sunday Tribune |date=19 August 1996 |accessdate=10 July 2011}} Prof. Makgoba has been closely involved with the funding in 2011 of a new 4,000 square metre HIV and [[tuberculosis]] research Institute, KwaZulu-Natal Research Institute for TB and HIV (KRITH) at the university's medical school.{{cite news |title=At the forefront of research|author=Greg Dardagan |url=http://www.gate5.co.za/qv/pr/12388977/14908480/9221/p |newspaper=Mercury |date=2 December 2010|accessdate=6 February 2012}} ==Achievements== ===Scientific contributions=== Working with Drs. Martin Sanders and Stephen Shaw and others at the National Cancer Institute, "were among the first to appreciate the importance of lymphocyte adhesion and these observations have helped shape the evolution of the field as follows:{{cite web|last=Shaw|first=J. Stephen|title=Our Science – Shaw Website|url=http://ccr.cancer.gov/staff/staff.asp?profileid=5658|work=J. Stephen Shaw MD NIH|publisher=National Cancer Institute|accessdate=9 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309163648/http://ccr.cancer.gov/staff/staff.asp?profileid=5658|archivedate=9 March 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=National Research Foundation honours Prof Makgoba|url=http://m.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/149/63695.html|accessdate=9 February 2012|newspaper=BizCommunity|date=5 September 2011}}{{cite web|title=Mainstays of research|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2011-09-02-mainstays-of-research|publisher=''Mail & Guardian''|accessdate=2 September 2011}} * appreciation of the importance of antigen-nonspecific [[cell adhesion|adhesion]] to [[T cell receptor|T cell antigen]]-specific recognition,{{cite journal|last=Makgoba|first=M.W|author2=Sanders, M.E |author3=Shaw, S |title=The CD2-LFA3 and LFA-1-ICAM1 pathways: relevance to T CEll recognition|journal=Immunology Today|year=1989|volume=10|pages=417–422|pmid=2482743|issue=12|doi=10.1016/0167-5699(89)90039-x}}{{cite web|last=ICSU|first=ICSU|title=Executive Board ICSU|url=http://www.icsu.org/about-icsu/structure/executive-board/?icsudocid=officers|accessdate=3 February 2012}}{{cite web|title=ISI Web of Knowledge|url=http://apps.webofknowledge.com/summary.do?SID=X1mhMK7nN%40PEO9pJojG&product=UA&qid=6&search_mode=GeneralSearch|publisher=THOMSON REUTERS|accessdate=9 February 2012}} * demonstration that changes in adhesion molecule expression and function are cardinal features of naïve to memory cell differentiation and{{cite journal|last=Makgoba|first=MW|author2=Sanders, M.E |author3=Shaw, S |title=Human naive and T memory Cells|journal=Immunology Today|year=1988|volume=9|pages=195–199|pmid=2978373|issue=7–8}} * for co-discovering the first two [[heterophillic]] direct intercellular molecular adhesion [[Metabolic pathway|pathway]]s in biology ". He was instrumental in demonstrating the importance of adhesion molecules in T cell function through a series of what are now regarded as classic publications. * Provided the first evidence that isoforms of the adhesion/ signaling molecule (ICAM-1) circulate in plasma and the circulating levels of isoform patterns might vary with inflammation and in different pathological states.{{cite journal|last=Makgoba|first=M.W|author2=Seth, R. |author3=Raymond, F |title=Circulating human 1CAM- 1 Isoforms. New diagnostic prospects for inflammatory and immune-related diseases|journal=The Lancet|date=13 July 1991|volume=338|pages=83–84|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0140673691900773|accessdate=15 February 2012|doi=10.1016/0140-6736(91)90077-3}} ===Fellowships and affiliations=== A former Deputy Vice-Chancellor at the University of Witwatersrand and ad hominem professor of molecular Immunology at the University of Witwatersrand's School of Pathology 1996-98, Professor Makgoba is * Fellow of the [[Royal College of Physicians]] of London 1990; * Founding Member of the Academy of Science of South Africa; * Fellow of the [[Royal Society of South Africa]] 1995; * Foreign Associate member of the United States [[National Academy of Sciences]]' [[Institute of Medicine]] 2002; * Fellow of the College of Physicians of South Africa ad eundem * Fellow of [[Imperial College]]'s Faculty of Medicine 2007 in recognition of contributions to "medical research, international public health and university administration". *Professor Makgoba was appointed as member of the National Planning Commission of the Republic of South Africa{{cite web|last=National Planning Commission|title=NPC Members|url=http://www.thepresidency.gov.za/pebble.asp?relid=|accessdate=9 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508120117/http://www.thepresidency.gov.za/pebble.asp?relid=|archivedate=8 May 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Makgoba takes on extra work for society|url=http://www.iol.co.za/mercury/makgoba-takes-on-extra-work-for-society-1.1153748|accessdate=9 February 2012}} *Professor Makgoba was a member of National Working Group appointed by the late Educational Minister Kadar Asmal in year 2000, that recommended mergers and incorporations in the restructuring of Higher Education system in South Africa.{{cite web|title=The Restructuring Of The Higher Education System In South Africa|url=http://www.info.gov.za/view/DownloadFileAction?id=70286|accessdate=14 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612080041/http://www.info.gov.za/view/DownloadFileAction?id=70286|archivedate=12 June 2011|df=dmy-all}} *In October 2011 he was elected as the new Vice-President for Scientific Planning and Review of the prestigious Paris-based International Council for Science (ICSU).{{cite news|last=Hartigh|first=Wilma den|title=South African academic elected to top council|url=http://www.mediaclubsouthafrica.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2612:science-council&catid=42:landnews&Itemid=110|accessdate=3 February 2012|newspaper=mediaclub}}{{cite web|title=Motion on the appointment of Professor Malegapuru Makgoba, 25 October 2011|url=http://www.anc.org.za/caucus/show.php?ID=2284|publisher=Parliamentary Caucus|accessdate=9 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304002355/http://www.anc.org.za/caucus/show.php?ID=2284|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} * Chosen as chair of the Ministerial Oversight Committee on Transformation in SA Public Universities [http://www.ukzn.ac.za/docs/media-releases/professor-malegapuru-makgoba-as-chair-of-the-ministerial-oversight-committee-on-transformation-in-sa-public-universities.pdf?sfvrsn=2 "Appointment of Professor Malegapuru Makgoba as Chair of the Ministerial Oversight Committee on Transformation in SA Public Universities"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140514112541/http://www.ukzn.ac.za/docs/media-releases/professor-malegapuru-makgoba-as-chair-of-the-ministerial-oversight-committee-on-transformation-in-sa-public-universities.pdf?sfvrsn=2 |date=14 May 2014 }}, University of KwaZulu-Natal, 13 December 2012. ===Awards=== * Science-for-Society Gold Medal of the Academy of Science South Africa in 2002 * Gold medal for Outstanding Leadership in Medical Research in 2001, University of the Witwatersrand * In October 2005, Makgoba received the Golden Jubilee Award of the Colleges of Medicine of South Africa in "recognition of his contribution in the field of Immunology and research, and particularly also in transforming research in South Africa while President of the Medical Research Council and for his role in transformation of Higher Education in South Africa" * In September 2011 Makgoba received the prestigious [[National Research Foundation of South Africa]]'s President's Lifetime Achievement Award for his "extraordinary contribution to the development of science".{{cite web|last=Mokoena|first=Palesa|title=NRF Awards Honour Professor Malegapuru William Makgoba with a Lifetime Achievement Award|url=http://nrfcoms.info/NRFPressroom/?p=450|work=Lifetime Achievement Award|publisher=NRF NewsRoom|accessdate=4 February 2012}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * Makgoba was the first recipient of the South African-German Science Award in the category of Top Researcher,“for having made outstanding extraordinary contribution(s) of international standard and impact to the development of science, in and for South Africa, over an extended period of time", 2012;{{cite web|title=UKZN's Makgoba honoured|url=http://www.iol.co.za/mercury/ukzn-s-makgoba-honoured-1.1399421#.UZ9Ck4cwdZg|publisher=''The Mercury''|accessdate=9 October 2012}} * Makgoba was honoured by President Jacob Zuma with the Order of Mapungubwe (Silver) "for his dedication and excellent contribution to the field of science and medicine, locally and internationally; and for his contribution to the building of democracy in South Africa. He is an outstanding academic and a pioneer of transformation in higher education."{{cite web|title=Prof. Malegapuru Makgoba honoured with the Order of Mapungubwe|url=http://www.icsu.org/news-centre/news/prof.-malegapuru-makgoba-honoured-with-the-order-of-mapungubwe|publisher=ISSU|accessdate=24 May 2013}} *The eThekwini Living Legends Award was awarded to Professor Malegapuru Makgoba for his critical contribution to the field of medicine. The Awards acknowledge individuals with "outstanding achievements, and those who have demonstrated a sustained and extraordinary contribution in various categories of expertise".{{cite web|title=eThekwini Living Legends Award|url=http://ethekwinilivinglegends.com/portfolio-items/professor-malegapuru-william-makgoba/|publisher=|accessdate=2013}} *Makgoba has been awarded the MRC President's Award for Exceptional Contributions to Medical Research. The Award was made in recognition of his exceptional contributions to medical research and is among the highest honours bestowed by the MRC.{{cite web|title=MRC President's Award for Exceptional Contributions to Medical Research|url=http://www.mrc.ac.za/publications/MRCSupplement2013.pdf|publisher=MRC|accessdate=2013}} ===Services to Committees and Boards=== *Chairperson of the Medical Research Council of South Africa, 1994–98; (reappointed) *First Secretary-General of the Academy of Science of South Africa, 1996–98; *Chairperson of the National Science and Technology Forum, 1995–99; *Member of the National Advisory Council on Innovation (NACI), 1998-2001(reappointed); *Member of the Council of Higher Education(CHE), 1998-2000; *Member of the Council on Higher Education's Quality Control Council, 1999-2000; *Member of the Presidential Advisory Panel on HIV/AIDS, 2000; *Member of the founding Board of Directors of the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative, 1999-2001; *Member of the UNAIDS/WHO Vaccine Committee and UNAIDS/WHO HIV/AIDS Prevention Group, 1999-2001; *Chairperson of the Board of Directors of the ''Mail and Guardian'' 2002 to March 2011; *Member of the National Advisory Council on Innovation (1998-2000), reappointed 2002; *Member of the Board of Directors of the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative, 1999-2004; *Founder member and founding Chairperson of the UNAIDS/WHO African Aids Vaccine Programme (AAVP), 2000–04; *Member of the Board of Directors of the Global Alliance for TB Drug Development (GATBD) 2000-04; *Member of the National Working Group appointed by Prof. Kader Asmal; *Chairperson of the Health Sciences Review Committee, since 2010-; *Member of the National Planning Commission since May 2010; *Chairperson of the Transformation Oversight Committee for Public Universities 2013. *Chairperson of a 10-member Medical Task Team established to investigate "factors affecting the optimal functioning of the three military hospitals in South Africa" - 2014 ==Transformation-related debates and controversies== ===Clashes with "inbred elite" at the University of the Witwatersrand=== Shortly after his appointment as deputy vice chancellor of Wits, Makgoba announced to ''[[The Times Higher Education Supplement]]'' that it was his intention to replace the university's "dominant eurocentrism", and called the university leadership a "small inbred elite" In response, 13 senior staff compiled a dossier contradicting claims made in his [[curriculum vitae]]. Makgoba responded with his own accusations, based on the personal files of the 13, of tax evasion, inconsistent salary scales, nepotism, lack of qualifications and misrepresentation of credentials. Makgoba was temporarily suspended by the university for abusing his position to access the academics' personal files. Journalist and biographer [[Mark Gevisser]] commented that "No intellectual debate defines our times more than that which racked the University of Witwatersrand in 1995"{{cite book|last=Gevisser|first=Mark|title=Portraits of Power: Profiles of a Changing South Africa|publisher=David Phillips|url=http://www.kalahari.com/books/Portraits-of-Power-Profiles-of-a-Changing-South-Africa-Profiles-in-a-Changing-South-Africa/632/234840.aspx|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130127103842/http://www.kalahari.com/books/Portraits-of-Power-Profiles-of-a-Changing-South-Africa-Profiles-in-a-Changing-South-Africa/632/234840.aspx|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-01-27}} [[Mahmood Mamdani]] stated that "Makogba was a victim of the 'racialised power' entrenched at Wits".{{cite journal|last=Mamdani|first=, M|title=Makgoba: victim of the 'racialised power' entrenched at Wits|journal=Source: SOCIAL DYNAMICS-A JOURNAL OF THE CENTRE FOR AFRICAN STUDIES UNIVERSITY OF CAPE TOWN|year=1997|volume=23|issue=2|pages=1–5|url=http://apps.webofknowledge.com/full_record.do?product=UA&search_mode=Refine&qid=2&SID=X1mhMK7nN@PEO9pJojG&page=1&doc=6|doi=10.1080/02533959708458629}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 1997, Makgoba published a book about his experiences at Wits, entitled ''Mokoko – The Makgoba Affair''.{{cite book|title=Mokoko: the Makgoba Affair : a reflection on transformation|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Mokoko.html?id=RMdCAQAAIAAJ&redir_esc=y|publisher=Vivlia Publishers, 1997|accessdate=7 February 2012}} In it, he affirmed his commitment to the idea of an [[African Renaissance]] and to "transforming the higher education landscape". Guy Martin, professor at the School of Government of the [[University of the Western Cape]], referred to the book as "a personal account of the recent process of transformation occurring at Wits."{{cite journal|last=Martin|first=Guy|title=Crisis in the Great Lakes|journal=African Studies Quarterly|year=1997|volume=1|issue=3|url=http://www.africa.ufl.edu/asq/v1/3/v1i3.pdf|accessdate=13 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121216233020/http://www.africa.ufl.edu/asq/v1/3/v1i3.pdf|archivedate=16 December 2012|df=dmy-all}} Martin noted that, while Makgoba was "justifiably proud of his considerable achievements as an African scientist", the force with which he defends his credentials in the book "leads him to sound intellectually pompous and arrogant and utterly self-centered, if not downright egocentric". Martin also questioned Makgoba's "resort to some unorthodox--and, possibly, unethical--methods of struggle", and noted his own "uneasiness in attempting to disentangle objective reality from opinion, and fact from fiction" while reading the book. Deputy President at the time, Thabo Mbeki, wrote: "The publication of this book demonstrates that it is possible to succeed in the struggle for change, despite the continuing exercise of power by powerful forces which owe their dominance to the very antithesis of "liberalism", however defined." ===White males as "baboons and bonobos"=== In 2005, ''The [[Mail and Guardian]]'' newspaper published an opinion piece by Professor Makgoba entitled "The wrath of the dethroned white male" which compared the behaviour of [[white South African]] males in post-Apartheid South Africa to "baboons or bonobos" who had lost their [[Alpha (ethology)|alpha status]], and were in need of "treatment and proper African rehabilitation".{{cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2005-03-25-wrath-of-dethroned-white-males|title=Wrath of dethroned white males|publisher=''Mail and Guardian''|author=Malegapuru Makgoba|date=25 March 2005}} This article was debated heavily in the press, and provoked a response the following week from Robert Morrell, a professor in the Faculty of Education at UKZN under Makgoba.{{cite news|author=Robert Morrell|title=White, male, democrat, African|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2005-04-01-white-male-democrat-african/|publisher=''Mail and Guardian''|date=1 April 2005}} In that article, Morrell argued that Makgoba's article could rightfully be interpreted as "bullying managerial practice". Later that year, Morrell brought a [[defamation]] case against Makgoba, primarily citing claims made about Morrell in an email sent out to staff.{{cite news|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=204881§ioncode=26|title=Alpha baboon article leads to libel case|author=Karen MacGregor|publisher=''Times Higher Education''|date=18 August 2006}} Morrell dropped the case three years later, following the death of his wife, and citing concern for his "own health and well-being".{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/morrel-drops-defamation-case-1.448779|author=Noelene Barbeau|title=Morrel drops defamation case|date=7 July 2009|publisher=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|Independent Online]]}} ===Accusations of stifling academic freedom at UKZN=== The Committee for Academic Freedom in Africa issued a statement in 2006 in protest against alleged infractions of academic freedom at the University of KwaZulu-Natal under Makgoba.{{cite web |url=http://www.ifex.org/en/content/view/full/78144 |title=Lecturer faces disciplinary committee, possible dismissal, as free expression declines at university |accessdate=18 November 2007 |date=10 October 2006 |publisher=Freedom of Expression Institute}} This partly arose from his treatment of critics, particularly those involved with the shack dwellers' movement [[Abahlali baseMjondolo]], of his ordering the eviction of shack dwellers living on the campus.{{cite web|url=http://abahlali.org/node/171|title=Shack dweller's press release}} Later that year he brought disciplinary action against one of the critics, UKZN academic Fazel Khan, for "bringing the university into disrepute", after Khan had answered questions put to him by the media after he was airbrushed out of a picture and removed from the text of an article on a film he had made that was printed in the University newsletter.{{cite web|url=http://squattercity.blogspot.com/2006/11/betrayal-and-colour-of-heart.html<<|title=Letter in support of Khan- 1 December 2006}} Later that year ''The Mercury'' newspaper reported that Makgoba had threatened to, at the request of the mayor of Durban, bring evidence from the National Intelligence Agency to the Council and to charge academics who had been working with the shack dweller's movement Abahlali baseMjondolo with "incitement".{{cite web|url=http://abahlali.org/node/167<<|title=Mercury article}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Staff were also banned from speaking to the media during a two-week strike in February 2006. Strikers wore T-shirts that read: "We Demand Academic Freedom".{{cite web|url=http://www.ukzn.ac.za/ccs/default.asp?3,43,10,2347<<|title=Pictures and text of the UKZN 2006 strike}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2007, the university senate invited faculties to make submissions on academic freedom.{{cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2008-04-15-ukzn-academics-question-senate-probe|author=Primarishni Gower|title=UKZN academics question senate probe|publisher=''Mail and Guardian''}} Preparation of the faculty of science and agriculture's submission was led by Professors Nithaya Chetty and John Van den Berg, who spoke to the press in April 2008 after Makgoba, as chairperson of the senate, blocked the submission several times, claiming that it was "self-serving and contributed nothing to the debate." Van den Berg and Chetty also voiced their frustrations that the submissions were to be investigated only by a one-man subcommittee of the senate, consisting of former education minister [[Sibusiso Bengu]], rather than being discussed in senate itself. Makgoba, as chair of the senate, blocked discussions of academic freedom. When Van den Berg criticised this, Makgoba accused him racism, cowardice, insubordination and lack of academic productivity.http://www.witness.co.za/index.php?showcontent&global%5B_id%5D=4944 Van den Berg voiced his frustrations in the press, and sent a letter to Makgoba which he also read out at a senate meeting. In response, in August 2008, the university brought disciplinary action against the two professors for having spoken to the press, in part for their criticism of Makgoba. They were charged with breaches of confidentiality, dishonesty and "gross negligence", and threatened with dismissal.{{cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2008-11-06-ukzn-carpets-critics|title=UKZN carpets critics|author=Primarishni Gower|publisher=''Mail and Guardian''}} Although the matter had initially been resolved by [[mediation]], this was rejected by university lawyers, who instead required that Chetty and Van den Berg sign admission of guilt forms, which they refused to do. Prof Alan Rycroft, representing the two professors, said of the matter, "As a labour lawyer, I have to question what kind of advice the legal team is giving to the vice-chancellor. If there has been misconduct, workplace discipline is meant to be corrective, not punitive." Professor Van den Berg reached an agreement with the university's lawyers. The terms included that the agreement would stand before the university council, that Van den Berg would express his regret and apologise unreservedly to the university, council, senate and to Makgoba for any harm that he may have caused, "reputationally or otherwise" and accept that senate had resolved that Makgoba was entitled to remove "academic freedom" from the senate agenda. The university agreed that Van den Berg had not been grossly negligent in claiming to the press that Makgoba had no right to do so. Van den Berg was also issued a final written warning and agreed never to make "disparaging remarks" about Makgoba in the media.{{cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politicsweb/view/politicsweb/en/page71619?oid=111944&sn=Detail|title="You have been vindicated" - Omar Moosa SC to Makgoba (personal communication)|author=Omar Moosa}} Professor Chetty resigned, citing concern for himself and his loved ones.{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/physics-professor-quits-ukzn-1.427056|title=Physics professor quits UKZN|publisher=[[Independent Online (South Africa)]]|date=27 November 2008}} A representative of the Freedom of Expression Institute, said of the resignation, "I think he was forced into a position where he felt he had to resign. The disciplinary process, with such expensive legal counsel, was set up so that the professors would lose." The disciplinary proceedings were condemned by several prominent national organisations, including the South African National Editors Forum,{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/silencing-of-staff-worries-sanef-1.424169|title=Silencing of staff worries Sanef|publisher=[[Independent Online (South Africa)]]|date=13 November 2008}} the [[Congress of South African Trade Unions]],{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/clean-up-your-act-ukzn-warned-1.428164|title=Clean up your act, UKZN warned|author=Agiza Hlongwane|publisher=Independent Online (South Africa)}} the Freedom of Expression Institute and the SA Mathematical Society.{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/ukzn-under-pressure-to-halt-action-on-profs-1.423961|title=UKZN under pressure to halt action on profs|publisher=Independent Online (South Africa)|author=Latoya Newman|date=14 November 2008}} South African Education minister at the time, [[Naledi Pandor]] raised concern over the "persistent negative publicity" the situation had generated. A Council Committee on Governance and Academic Freedom (GAFC) including former Public Protector Advocate Selby Baqwa was set up internally by the University. In 2009 it found that, although there were problems dealing with academics who spoke to the media and with the manner of conduct of disciplinary hearings, Makgoba and the university had not threatened academic freedom.{{cite news|last=Blaine|first=Sue|title=Varsity invites staff to join ‘freedom’ debate|url=http://www.businessday.co.za/Articles/Content.aspx?id=72264|accessdate=8 February 2012|newspaper=Businessday|date=2 June 2009}} This was in spite of "two years of repeated criticism, both locally and abroad, of its commitment to academic freedom.". In 2012, Makgoba,Karim and Coovadia stated in an [[advertorial]] published by the ''[[The Sunday Times (South Africa)|Sunday Times]]'' that UKZN had "followed a protracted legal struggle mounted to protect its scientific autonomy against official impediments to legitimate AIDS research"{{cite news|url=http://www.gate5.co.za/qv/pr/15425028/17967946/9221/t|newspaper=Sunday Times Zulu|title=University of KwaZulu-Natal successfully defends Scientific Autonomy in AIDS Research|date=5 February 2012|accessdate=20 February 2012}} ==Public stance against AIDS denialism== {{Main|AIDS_denialism#In_South_Africa}} During the late 1990s and early 2000s, President [[Thabo Mbeki]] invited several HIV/AIDS denialists to join his Presidential AIDS Advisory Panel,{{cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/news/0027,schoofs2,16283,1.html |title=Debating the Obvious: Inside the South African Government's Controversial AIDS Panel |last=Schoofs |first=M |work=[[Village Voice]] |date=5 July 2000 |accessdate=11 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617232941/http://www.villagevoice.com/news/0027%2Cschoofs2%2C16283%2C1.html |archivedate=17 June 2008 |df= }} resulting in government policies that have since been estimated to have led to the early deaths of more than 330,000 South Africans.{{cite journal |vauthors=Chigwedere P, Seage GR, Gruskin S, Lee TH, Essex M |title=Estimating the Lost Benefits of Antiretroviral Drug Use in South Africa |journal=Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes |volume= 49|issue= 4|pages= 410–415|date=October 2008 |pmid=19186354 |doi=10.1097/QAI.0b013e31818a6cd5 |laysummary=http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/press-releases/2008-releases/researchers-estimate-lives-lost-delay-arv-drug-use-hivaids-south-africa.html}}{{cite journal |author=Nattrass N |title=Estimating the Lost Benefits of Antiretroviral Drug Use in South Africa |journal=African Affairs |volume=107 |issue=427 |pages=157–76 |date=February 2008 |doi=10.1093/afraf/adm087 }} At the time, Makgoba as President of the Medical Research Council took a leading role in the fight against AIDS denialism and the right for the freedom of scientific inquiry and was signatory and co-editor of the "Durban Declaration on HIV and AIDS" in July 2000.http://www.aegis.org/news/dmg/2000/MG000710.html{{cite web|title=The tragic Cost of Being Unscientific|url=http://www.aidstruth.org/print/113|publisher=Aids Truth.org|accessdate=7 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707003350/http://www.aidstruth.org/print/113|archivedate=7 July 2010|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Politics, the media and science in HIV/AIDS: the peril of pseudoscience|url=https://www.ualberta.ca/~dcl3/hype/politics+media+sicnece+in+HIV+AIDS_Peril+of+pseudoscience.pdf|publisher=Vaccine 20 (2002) 1899–1904|accessdate=7 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120913172603/http://www.ualberta.ca/~dcl3/hype/politics%2Bmedia%2Bsicnece%2Bin%2BHIV%2BAIDS_Peril%2Bof%2Bpseudoscience.pdf|archive-date=13 September 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|last=Cohen|first=Jon|title=A Research Renaissance, South African Style|url=http://aidscience.org/Science/Cohen288(5474)2169.html|publisher=''Science Magazine'', 23 June 2000, Volume 288, Number 5474}} ==False allegations of sexual harassment== Makgoba, along with the council chairman, stepped aside from their positions on 28 November 2006, after a scandal emerged involving claims of sexual harassment and victimisation levelled by the dean of the Faculty of Management Studies, Pumela Msweli-Mbanga. Judge Magid chaired the enquiry into the sexual harassment allegations.{{cite news|author=SAPA|title=UKZN set tribunal for Makgoba, Maphai probe|url=http://www.sundaytribune.co.za/ukzn-set-tribunal-for-makgoba-maphai-probe-1.306082|accessdate=8 February 2012|newspaper=Sunday Tribune|date=4 December 2006}} Makgoba denied these claims and relinquished his post pending the outcome of an enquiry.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessday.co.za/articles/topstories.aspx?ID=BD4A329611<|title=Business Day|date= 1 December 2006}} Makgoba was subsequently found not guilty and resumed his position as Vice-Chancellor.{{cite news |title=University heads cleared of harassment charges |author=Karen MacGregor |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=207673§ioncode=26 |newspaper=Times Higher Education |date= 2 February 2007|accessdate=2 February 2012}} The dean of management studies was found to have had an intimate relationship with the university's chief financial officer, Kanthan Pillay, to whom she granted a master's degree which was later rescinded for "multiple irregularities". Msweli-Mbanga filed the sexual harassment charges in response to initial investigations into the awarding of the degree. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.ukzn.ac.za/ University of KwaZulu-Natal official site] * [https://archive.is/20130707091209/http://vc.ukzn.ac.za/ Malegapuru Makgoba's website (website of the Vice Chancellor of UKZN)] {{Order of Mapungubwe}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Makgoba, Malegapuru William}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South African immunologists]] [[Category:Academic freedom]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal College of Physicians]] [[Category:University of Natal faculty]]

{{Infobox artist | name = Marion Koogler McNay | image = Marion Koogler McNay.jpg | imagesize = 150px | caption = Marion Koogler McNay, 1915 | birth_name = Jessie Marion Koogler | birth_date = {{Birth date|1883|2|7|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[De Graff, Ohio|De Graff]], [[Ohio]], United States[http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fmc98 Marion Koogler McNay], Handbook of Texas Online, [[University of Texas at Austin]], 2001-06-01. Accessed 2007-10-08. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1950|4|13|1883|2|7|df=yes}} | death_place = [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]], United States | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | field = [[Painting|Painter]] | training = | movement = | works = | patrons = | awards = }} '''Marion Koogler McNay''' (7 February 1883 – 13 April 1950), was an American [[Painting|painter]] and art teacher who inherited a substantial oil fortune upon the death of her father. She later willed her fortune to be used to establish San Antonio's first museum of [[modern art]], which today [[Marion Koogler McNay Art Museum|bears her name]].Burkhalter, Lois Wood. ''Marion Koogler McNay: A Biography, 1883-1950'' (San Antonio: Marion Koogler McNay Art Institute, 1968) == Early life == Marion was born in [[Ohio]] to Marion and Clara Koogler. A year after her birth, the family moved to [[El Dorado, Kansas|El Dorado]], [[Kansas]], where her parents purchased a large tract of pasture land. This land later proved to contain substantial oil reserves, and made the family wealthy. This allowed Marion to attend the [[University of Kansas]] and the [[Art Institute of Chicago]]. == Marriages == Marion married her first husband, railway manager Don McNay, in 1917. The marriage only lasted 10 months, ending with Don's death from [[influenza]]. Although Marion went on to marry (and [[divorce]]) four more times, she eventually reverted to using the name McNay for the remainder of her life. She married and financially supported artist [[Victor Higgins]] in 1937, but the two separated only two years later and divorced in 1930.{{cite book|last1=Porter|first1=Dean|title=Taos Artists and Their Patrons, 1898-1950|date=1999|publisher=Snite Museum of Art|location=Notre Dame, Indiana|isbn=0826321097|pages=144–151}} == Teaching == In 1915, while she was living with her parents, the superintendent of city schools of [[Marion, Ohio]] wrote that she
''is one of the best qualified art teachers I have ever known. She teaches art in a manner that arouses and develops the child’s observation and enlarges his aesthetic nature.''Biography. "Dedicated to the Advancement and the Enjoyment of Modern Art." Teacher Resource Center at the McNay Art Museum. [http://www.mcnaytrc.org/history.htm]
== Art collection == In 1926, after the death of her father, Marion moved to [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]] with her mother and married Dr. Donald Atkinson. On his property, she began to construct a Spanish Mediterranean style mansion (she designed some of the tilework and ceiling stencils herself), which was completed in 1927.[http://www.fada.com/browse_by_artist.html?gallery_no=3&artist=3564&bio=1 Marion Koogler McNay] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061015205311/http://www.fada.com/browse_by_artist.html?gallery_no=3&artist=3564&bio=1 |date=2006-10-15 }}, Fine Art Dealers' Association. Accessed 2007-10-08. She also began to accumulate a significant collection of artwork. The first oil painting she purchased was [[Diego Rivera]]’s ''Delfina Flores''. She collected a large number of French [[Impressionist]] and [[Post-Impressionist]] works of art, early 20th-century [[modernists]] including [[Picasso]], [[Matisse]], and [[Chagall]]. She also bought a number of Southwestern [[Santo (art)|santos]] and [[retablos]]. == Pueblo Indian patronage == Marion was a significant patron of the arts among the [[Pueblo Indians]] of [[New Mexico]], where she made frequent trips. In 1943, [[United States Congress|Congress]] proposed a bill providing for the exploration of Pueblo lands with the ultimate goal of building a dam on the [[Rio Grande]]. Marion, in conjunction with other [[conservation movement|conservationist]]s, was instrumental in defeating this proposal. == Death and art museum establishment == Upon Marion's death, caused by pneumonia in 1950, she willed her fortune, her art collection, and her home to a trust to convert her home into a modern art museum. This was the first museum of its kind in San Antonio and the Southwest region of the United States. The museum was named after her, and has been expanded to include galleries of [[medieval art|medieval]] and [[Renaissance]] artwork and a larger collection of 20th-century European and American modernist work. A large theatre arts library and gallery were also added, as well as an art reference library and an auditorium. More recently, the [[McNay Art Museum]] recently added the Stieren Center, built by internationally renowned architect [[Jean-Paul Viguier]], to display their Modern collection. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McNay, Marion Koogler}} [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1950 deaths]] [[Category:People from Logan County, Ohio]] [[Category:People from El Dorado, Kansas]] [[Category:University of Kansas alumni]] [[Category:School of the Art Institute of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:People from San Antonio]] [[Category:Painters from Texas]] [[Category:Painters from Ohio]] [[Category:Artists from Kansas]] [[Category:20th-century American painters]] [[Category:American art collectors]] [[Category:Women art collectors]] [[Category:Art educators]]

{{Infobox School |name =Maurice-Tièche Comprehensive School |native_name =L’Ensemble Scolaire Maurice-Tièche |image =Maurice_Tieche_logo.jpg |imagesize =189px |caption = |streetaddress = 545 chemin de Bottecreux |region =74165 Collonges-sous-Salève |postcode = BP 74 |country =FRA |coordinates = |denomination = [[Seventh-day Adventist]] |affiliation = |trustee = |founder =Maurice Tièche |specialist = |chairperson =Richard Lehmann |principal =Laurent Hernicot |viceprincipal = |dean = |administrator = |chaplain = |teaching_staff = 23 |roll = |ceeb = |testaverage = |testname = |national_ranking = |classes = |classes offered = |avg_class_size =20 students |gender =Mixed |lower_age =2 |upper_age =18 |houses = |schooltype =[[Private school|Private]], [[Co-educational]], [[Boarding school]] |system = |fees =Years 7 to 10 - €867 (term)
Years 11 to 13 - €1024 (term) |enrolment = |language = French |classrooms = |campus = |campus size = |campus type = |hours_in_day = |athletics = |slogan = |song = |motto = |motto_translation = |accreditation =[[Adventist Accrediting Association]][http://www.adventistyearbook.org/default.aspx?page=ViewEntity&EntityID=13736 "Adventist Yearbook"]. General Conference Office of Statistics & Archives. Retrieved 2009-07-19 |sports =Mountain Sports |team_name = |nickname = |school_colours = |established = 1936 |students = |free_label =Séries L |free_text =95% |free_label1 =Séries S |free_text1 =77% |picture = |homepage = {{nowrap|http://www.m-tieche.net/}} }} {{Seventh-day Adventism}} '''L’Ensemble Scolaire Maurice-Tièche''' or '''Maurice Tièche Comprehensive School''' is a K-13 [[co-educational]], [[Christian]] [[Private school|private]] school owned by the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] in the region [[Collonges-sous-Salève]] of [[France]]. It teaches pupils of [[Primary school|primary]], [[Junior high school|junior high]] and [[Senior high school|senior high]] school age. The school also has a [[nursery school]] offering care to 2 year-olds. It is a part of the [[Seventh-day Adventist education|Seventh-day Adventist education system]], the world's second largest Christian school system.http://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/Opinion/2010/1115/For-real-education-reform-take-a-cue-from-the-Adventists"the{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} second largest Christian school system in the world has been steadily outperforming the national average – across all demographics."{{cite web|url=http://www.religionfacts.com/christianity/denominations/seventh_day_adventist.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-03-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150323223151/http://www.religionfacts.com/christianity/denominations/seventh_day_adventist.htm |archivedate=2015-03-23 |df= }}{{cite web |title=Department of Education, Seventh-day Adventist Church |url=http://education.gc.adventist.org/about.html |accessdate=2010-06-18 }} {{cite web |url=http://news.adventist.org/2003/04/worl-church-a-closer-look-at-higher-eucatio.html |title=World Church: A Closer Look at Higher Education |first=Wendi |last=Rogers |first2=Mark A. |last2=Kellner |date=April 1, 2003 |publisher=[[Adventist News Network]] |accessdate=2010-06-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724224535/http://news.adventist.org/2003/04/worl-church-a-closer-look-at-higher-eucatio.html |archivedate=July 24, 2011 |df= }} ==History== The Maurice-Tièche primary school was founded in 1936 by Maurice Tièche, a graduate from the historic [[University of Paris]] (commonly referred to as [[La Sorbonne]]). In October 1946, the first year 7 (6ème) class was opened. In October 1948, the rest of the [[junior high school]] was opened and the school was renamed ''Le Cours Complémentaire du Séminaire Adventiste''. In 1953, the [[junior high school]] became a [[secondary school]] under the name ''le Cours Secondaire''. Over 100 pupils were enrolled at that time. In 1973, the [[secondary school]] adopted the name ''Cours Privé Maurice Tièche'', then some years later, it became ''Lycée Privé Maurice Tièche''. The [[Primary school|primary]] and [[secondary schools]] merged into a combined school in 2003 which is now known as ''Ensemble Scolaire Maurice Tièche''.[http://www.m-tieche.net/groupe-scolaire-prive/fondement.php "History"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408192102/http://www.m-tieche.net/groupe-scolaire-prive/fondement.php |date=2009-04-08 }}. Maurice Tieche Combined School. Retrieved 2009-07-19 ==Facilities== Pupils at the school have access to [[Adventist University of France – Collonges#Alfred Vaucher Library|Bibliothèque Alfred Vaucher]] (Alfred Vaucher Library) which it shares with the [[Adventist University of France – Collonges|Saleve Adventist University]].[http://www.bibavaucher.net/ "About Alfred Vaucher Library"]. Alfred Vaucher Library. Retrieved 2009-07-19 The ''Section Etudes et Sports de Montagne'' (Studies and Mountain Sports section) of the school allows pupils to combine their high school studies and their passion for mountain sports.[http://www.maurice-tieche.fr/esm "Section Etudes et Sports de Montagne"]. Maurice Tieche Combined School. Retrieved 2009-07-19 Preparatory classes start at year 9 but it is possible for students to take up the cycle in senior high school. ==Academics== The school has three [[Baccalauréat]] général streams in which students can specialise in: * '''S''' Scientifique (sciences) * '''ES''' Sciences économiques et sociales (economics and social sciences) * '''L''' littéraire (literature) Since 2002, the pass rate for the [[Baccalauréat]] scientifique (Sciences) stream has been around 77% while in the littéraire (literature) stream, is around 95%.[http://www.m-tieche.net/groupe-scolaire-prive/college-lycee/lycee.php "Lycée"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417004138/http://www.m-tieche.net/groupe-scolaire-prive/college-lycee/lycee.php |date=2009-04-17 }}. Maurice Tieche Combined School. Retrieved 2009-07-19 The students in première (Year 12) and terminale (Year 13) are generally in classes of 12 in each of their respective streams. In certain subjects such as French where the programme is joint, students come together to form classes of a maximum of 24 students. This allows teachers to track individual students and address many of their questions. ==See also== {{Portal|Seventh-day Adventist Church|Christianity|Schools|France}} * [[List of Seventh-day Adventist secondary and elementary schools]] * [[Seventh-day Adventist education]] * [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] * [[Seventh-day Adventist theology]] * [[History of the Seventh-day Adventist Church]] *[[List of schools in France]] *[[Adventist University of France – Collonges|Saleve Adventist University]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.maurice-tieche.fr/esm Section Etudes et Sports de Montagne] *[http://www.bibavaucher.net/ Bibliothèque Alfred Vaucher] *[http://www.campusadventiste.edu/ Saleve Adventist University] {{coord missing|France}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maurice-Tieche Comprehensive School}} [[Category:Secondary schools affiliated with the Seventh-day Adventist Church]] [[Category:Education in France]] [[Category:Secondary schools in France]] [[Category:Private schools in France]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1936]]

page.title: National Museum of Natural History and Science, Lisbon

revision.text:
[[File:Escola Politécnica de Lisboa.jpg|300px|thumbnail|right|Façade of the National Museum of Natural History and Science, at Rua da Escola Politécnica, Lisbon]] The '''National Museum of Natural History and Science''' in [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]] ({{lang-pt|Museu Nacional de História Natural e da Ciência}}) is the country's main museum focusing on nature. Established in 1926, the museum functions under the [[University of Lisbon]].
Its rich collections, gathered over more than 250 years, span [[zoology]], [[anthropology]], [[geology]] and [[botany]].
The museum has activities for the promotion of natural history and science awareness, with space for artistic exhibitions, conferences, debates, workshops and courses.
==History==
Its public designation is "MUjHNAC - National Museum of Natural History and Science". It was founded in October 2011. This unit incorporated the former National Museum of Natural History and the [[University of Lisbon]] Science Museum, integrating their collections, the old buildings of the Polytechnic School, the Lisbon Botanical Gardens and the Lisbon Astronomical Observatory (this one since July 2012):<ref name="m">{{cite web|url=http://www.mnhnc.ul.pt|title=History of the National Museum of Natural History and Science|accessdate=}}</ref>
MUjHNAC began in the Royal Natural History Museum and Botanical Garden, created in the second half of the eighteenth century, in [[Ajuda]] (western Lisbon). It was then housed for a short period in the Royal Academy of Sciences and transferred to the Polytechnic School (1858), first denominated as the National Museum of Lisbon (1861).
The Botanic Gardens of Lisbon officially opened in 1878.
In 1911, with the creation of the University of Lisbon, the Museum was attached to the Faculty of Sciences, taking the name of National Museum of Natural History in 1926.
In March 1978 a devastating fire destroyed much of the building of the former Polytechnic School, as well as the zoology collection and part of the geology collection. The Faculty then moved to other premises.
The Science Museum of the University of Lisbon was created in May 1985, sharing the building with the National Museum of Natural History.
Both museums were given new bylaws in 2003, becoming autonomous from the Faculty of Sciences and under the direct administration of the Rector of the University of Lisbon.
==See also== * [[University of Lisbon]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.museus.ulisboa.pt}}
{{coord|38|45|19.65|N|9|9|41.26|W|type:landmark_region:PT|format=dms|display=title}}
[[Category:Natural history museums in Portugal]] [[Category:National museums of Portugal]] [[Category:Museums established in 1926]] [[Category:Museums in Lisbon]] [[Category:University of Lisbon]] [[Category:University museums]]
{{Portugal-museum-stub}}

[[File:Black lung screening.jpg|thumb|right|A Radiographer explains an x-ray to a coal miner participating in screening. Patient education can include explaining the results of diagnostic tests.]] '''Patient education''' is the process by which [[health professional]]s and others impart information to patients and their caregivers that will alter their health behaviors or improve their health status.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://odphp.osophs.dhhs.gov/pubs/GUIDECPS/text/iv_edu.txt|title=iv. Patient Education and Counseling for Prevention|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421064558/http://odphp.osophs.dhhs.gov/pubs/GUIDECPS/text/iv_edu.txt|archivedate=April 21, 2014|deadurl=y}}</ref>
==Overview== Education may be provided by any healthcare professional who has undertaken appropriate training education, education on patient communication and education is usually included in the healthcare professional's training.
[[Health education]] is also a tool used by [[managed care]] plans, and may include both general [[Preventive medicine|preventive]] education or [[health promotion]] and disease or condition specific education.<ref>Peter R. Koongstvedt, "The Managed Health Care Handbook," Fourth Edition, Aspen Publishers, Inc., 2001, page 788 {{ISBN|0-8342-1726-0}}</ref>
Important elements of patient education are skill building and responsibility: patients need to know when, how, and why they need to make a lifestyle change. Group effort is equally important: each member of the patient’s health care team needs to be involved.It can also help the patients by a better lifestyle, it give them the ability to learn new information.
The value of patient education can be summarized as follows: *Improved understanding of medical condition, diagnosis, disease, or disability. *Improved understanding of methods and means to manage multiple aspects of medical condition. *Improved self-advocacy in deciding to act both independently from medical providers and in interdependence with them. *Increased Compliance – Effective communication and patient education increases patient motivation to comply. *Patient Outcomes – Patients more likely to respond well to their treatment plan – fewer complications. *Informed Consent – Patients feel you've provided the information they need. *Utilization – More effective use of medical services – fewer unnecessary phone calls and visits. *Satisfaction and referrals – Patients more likely to stay with your practice and refer other patients.<ref>[http://www.krames.com Krames Patient Education]</ref> *Risk Management – Lower risk of malpractice when patients have realistic expectations.<ref>[http://www.patient-education.com/?p=editorial&s=xplainresearch&ver=~2 Patient Education Institute, Research evidence]</ref>
The competencies of a [[health educator]] include the following:<ref>{{cite book|last=Bastable|first=Susan B.|title=Health Professionals as Educator|year=2011|publisher=Jones & Barlett Learning, LLC|location=Sudbury, MA|pages=6}}</ref> *Incorporate a personal ethic in regards to social responsibilities and services towards others. *Provide accurate, competent, and evidence-based care. *Practice preventative health care. *Focus on relationship-centered care with individuals and their families. *Incorporate the multiple determinants of health when providing care. *Be culturally sensitive and be open to a diverse society. *Use technology appropriately and effectively. *Be current in the field and continue to advance education. There are many areas where patient education can improve the outcomes of treatment. * For example, in patients with amputations, patient education has been shown to be effective when approached from all angles by the healthcare team (nurse, primary care physician, prosthetist, physical therapist, occupational therapist etc.). Support groups have been shown to be a helpful method for dealing with depression in this population. Preoperative patient education helped patients with their decision making process by informing them of factors related to pain, limb loss, and functional restriction faced after amputation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pantera|first=E.|last2=Pourtier-Piotte|first2=C.|last3=Bensoussan|first3=L.|last4=Coudeyre|first4=E.|title=Patient education after amputation: Systematic review and experts’ opinions|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1877065714000165|journal=Annals of Physical and Rehabilitation Medicine|volume=57|issue=3|pages=143–158|doi=10.1016/j.rehab.2014.02.001}}</ref> * In the case of arthritis, patient education was found to be administered through three methods, including individual face to face meetings with healthcare professionals, patient groups, online support programs. Category I evidence was found for individual, face to face counseling. Meeting with rheumatologists, occupational therapists, physical therapists, nurses, and other healthcare providers was found to be effective in creating adherence to treatment, medication, and for improving overall patient health.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zangi|first=Heidi A.|last2=Ndosi|first2=Mwidimi|last3=Adams|first3=Jo|last4=Andersen|first4=Lena|last5=Bode|first5=Christina|last6=Boström|first6=Carina|last7=Eijk-Hustings|first7=Yvonne van|last8=Gossec|first8=Laure|last9=Korandová|first9=Jana|date=2015-06-01|title=EULAR recommendations for patient education for people with inflammatory arthritis|url=http://ard.bmj.com/content/74/6/954|journal=Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases|language=en|volume=74|issue=6|pages=954–962|doi=10.1136/annrheumdis-2014-206807|issn=1468-2060|pmid=25735643}}</ref> * In the case of [[rheumatoid arthritis]], patient education has been shown as an effective non-pharmacological treatment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brosseau|first=Lucie|last2=Rahman|first2=Prinon|last3=Poitras|first3=Stéphane|last4=Toupin-April|first4=Karine|last5=Paterson|first5=Gail|last6=Smith|first6=Christine|last7=King|first7=Judy|last8=Casimiro|first8=Lynn|last9=Angelis|first9=Gino De|title=A Systematic Critical Appraisal of Non-Pharmacological Management of Rheumatoid Arthritis with Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation II|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0095369|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=9|issue=5|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0095369|pmc=4026323|pmid=24840205}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Compliance (medicine)]] *[[Green prescription]] *[[Managed care]] *[[Medical writing]] *[[Orem model of nursing]]

Patient Education in Health and Illness (5th ed.). Philadelphia, PA: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins * Bastable, S.B, Grambet, P., Jacobs, K., Sopczyk, D.L. (2011). [[File:Silver-McLean teaching-methodology.png|thumb]] '''Pete Silver & Will McLean''' are two British architectural practitioners, educators, writers, and technical theorists who work together as a duo. They have taught at the [[Architectural Association]], [[The Bartlett]] ([[University College London]]), and The [[University of Westminster]]'s School of Architecture and the Built environment, thus gaining a privileged position in the contemporary London architectural scene.
==Background== Will McLean is a Doctor of Philosophy and artist [[Bruce McLean]]<ref>Bruce McLean has been engaging with architecture for over twenty years through an ongoing collaboration with [[Will Alsop]] on such buildings as the proposed 151 City Road, London: http://www.skyscrapernews.com/news.php?ref=866</ref>'s son. He trained at the [[Architectural Association]] under [[Will Alsop]] OBE RA and Professor [[John Frazer (architect)|John Frazer]]. McLean has worked on a series of projects with Bruce McLean, most notably Dalry Primary School in North Ayrshire completed in 2007 (www.primaryspace.net), and with US architect and artist Adam Kalkin,<ref>http://www.architectureandhygiene.com (free download)</ref> working on such projects as 'Quik Build' container housing. He has had a regular feature, covering technical innovations, in Architectural Design magazine - McLean's Nuggets, and is an Editor of Construction History - the International Journal of the Construction History Society[[File:Dalry.jpg|thumb|Dalry Primary School]] Pete Silver worked for Solon [[Housing Association]] in South London with architects such as [[Patrick Keiller]], [[Edward Cullinan]] and [[Walter Segal]]. He trained at the [[Architectural Association]] under Professors [[John Frazer (architect)|John Frazer]] and [[Gordon Pask]], and became a researcher in the Land Use Research Unit at [[King's College London]], gaining a unique insight into Professor [[Alice Coleman]]'s groundbreaking, if controversial work, on post-war housing [[urban regeneration|regeneration]]. Silver is a director of the Chartered Practice Architects (CPA) Ltd. His current work involves prototyping new structural (diagrid) frameworks from torsional elastic helixes. [[File:R0018207.JPG|thumb|Torsional Diagrid]]
==Collaborative career== In 2001, Silver and McLean joined the School of Architecture and the Built environment at the [[University of Westminster]] where they jointly head the Technical Studies Department.<!-- TEACHING ETHOS. --> They have co-authored four architecture books: ''Fabrication: the designer's guide'' (Architectural Press), ''Introduction to Architectural Technology'' (Laurence King Publishing - available in 7 languages), ''Structural Engineering for Architects: A Handbook'' (Laurence King Publishing, co-authored with engineer Peter Evans - available in 4 languages) and Air Structures (Laurence King Publishing). They co-curate a highly successful public lecture series,
== Bibliography == '''Books'''
*Frazer J.H (1995), An Evolutionary Architecture, Themes VII, Architectural Association, London, UK. (Contributions by Silver) (out of print but free download at http://www.aaschool.ac.uk/publications/ea/intro.html) *Silver, Pete and McLean, William and Veglio, Simon (2006) Fabrication: the designers guide: the illustrated works of twelve specialist UK fabricators, Architectural Press, Oxford, UK. {{ISBN|0-7506-6558-0}} *Silver, Pete and McLean, William (2008) An Introduction to Architectural Technology, Laurence King, London, UK {{ISBN|978-1-85669-566-4}} (Second Edition published 2013) *Silver, Pete and McLean, William and Evans, Peter (2014) Structural Engineering for Architects: A Handbook, Laurence King, London, UK ISBN 978 -1-78067-055-3 *McLean, William and Silver, Pete (2015) Air Structures, Laurence King (in the series Form + Technique), London, UK{{ISBN|978-1-78067-482-7}} *McLean, William (2008) Quik Build: Adam Kalkin’s ABC of Container Architecture, Bibliothèque McLean, London, UK {{ISBN|978-0-9558868-0-5}} * (Also in the series Form + Technique, see: Rivas Adrover, Esther (2015) Deployable Structures, Laurence King, London, UK {{ISBN|978-1-78067-483-4}}) '''Periodicals'''

Magazine, Architectural Design Profile No 123. *Silver et al., (2001) Prototypical Applications of Cybernetic Systems in Architectural Contexts, In: Kybernetes, Volume 30 Number 7/8. *McLean, William (2005–2009) McLean's nuggets. In: Architectural Design (various). Wiley, hichester, UK.

{{EngvarB|date=May 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox University | image_name = Presbyterian university college logo.png | image_size = 124 × 104px | caption = Presbyterian University College, Ghana | name = Presbyterian University College, Ghana (PUCG) | motto = Discipline in Leadership | established = 23 November 2003<ref name="est"/> | type = [[Private university|Private/Public]] | affiliation = Christian (Presbyterian) | endowment = | chairman = Dr. Stephen Saforo Yirenkyi | chancellor = vacant | vice_chancellor = | president = Rev. Prof. Emmanuel Adow Obeng | principal = | rector = | city =[[Abetifi|Abetifi-Kwahu]] | state = | country = [[Ghana]] | coor = | undergrad = | postgrad = | staff = | campus = Okwahu (Abetifi), Asante-Akyem (Agogo), Akuapem (Akropong), Tema, Kumasi | mascot = | free_label = | free = | website = [http://www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh/ www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh] | logo = | footnotes = }} The '''Presbyterian University College, Ghana''' is a partially [[private university|private & public university]] located at [[Abetifi|Abetifi-Kwahu]] in the [[Eastern Region (Ghana)|Eastern Region]] of [[Ghana]]. It is one of the new universities in Ghana granted accreditation by the National Accreditation Board.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nab.gov.gh/nabsite/pages/accredited_institute3.php?skey=unicol&Search=Search |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019045941/http://www.nab.gov.gh/nabsite/pages/accredited_institute3.php?skey=unicol&Search=Search |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-19 |title=Accredited Institutions – University Colleges |accessdate=2007-03-14 |year=2005 |work= |publisher=National Accreditation Board }}</ref> It was established by the [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana]] on 23 November 2003<ref name="est">{{cite web |url=http://www.presbyunifound.org/college.htm |title=Presbyterian University College – Historical Background |accessdate=2007-03-14 |year=2006 |work=Official website |publisher=Presbyterian University College Foundation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928004641/http://www.presbyunifound.org/college.htm |archivedate=28 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and inaugurated on 27 March 2004 by the president of Ghana, [[John Agyekum Kufuor]].<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/education/artikel.php?ID=54855 |title=Presbyterian University College Inaugurated |accessdate=2007-03-14 |date=27 March 2004 |work=Ghanaweb.com |publisher=Ghana Home Page |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610065708/http://ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/education/artikel.php?ID=54855 |archivedate=10 June 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It has been ranked the best private university in Ghana and third best after the [[University of Ghana]] and [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology|KNUST]] by world university ranking website [http://www.webometrics.info/en/Africa/Ghana webometrics].
== History and background == Per historical accounts, the [[Presbyterian Church of Ghana]] established Ghana's first elementary school in the country in 1843 which resulted in the institutionalization of [[Formal learning|formal education]] in the country.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh/site/|title=Presbyterian University College, Ghana {{!}} Discipline in Leadership|website=www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912011629/http://www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh/site/|archivedate=12 September 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In 1848, the church founded a teacher-catechist seminary, the Basel Mission Seminary, later known as the Presbyterian Training College (PTC) at [[Akropong]] as the second higher educational institution in West Africa after [[Fourah Bay College]] in [[Sierra Leone]]. This development led to the establishment of several primary and secondary schools and colleges of education through a strategic partnership with the [[Government of Ghana|Ghanaian government]]; specifically, 1,886 schools made up of 490 kindergartens, 973 primary school, 388 junior secondary schools, 25 senior secondary schools, five vocational institutes and five colleges of education.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" /> The church has also been instrumental in providing agricultural and health services for citizens.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" />
The initial plan was to upgrade the Presbyterian Training College at Akropong to a full-fledged university like [[Fourah Bay College]] but that did no come into fruition.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" /> More than a century and a half later, the Synod of the Presbyterian Church during its 1996 conference voted to establish an actual university culminating in the setting up of an Implementation Committee in 1998.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" /> The university sought to augment higher education services to meet to increasing demand for college education.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" /> Despite its religious affiliation, the university college welcome students of all backgrounds, ethnicity, religion and geography.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" /> The school runs a fee-paying, multi-campus, residential or hostel system in partnership with private enterprise.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Its academic programs are in humanities and social sciences, particularly theology, language and mission studies.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" /> The school also offers programs in science and technology including health sciences, medicine, dentistry and nursing.<ref name="est" /><ref name=":1" /> [[File:Presbyterian University College Entrance.jpg|alt=Presbyterian University College|thumb|318x318px|Presbyterian University College]]
== Objectives == The stated objectives in the institutions statutes are as follows:<ref name=":1" /> * ''"To provide for and promote University education, learning and research,'' * ''To acquire and disseminate knowledge and information,'' * ''To foster relationships with other institutions of higher learning, persons and bodies.'' * ''To produce disciplined, self-motivated individuals and leaders with moral and intellectual values in the realization of their responsibilities to God, fellow citizens and the state.''" Furthermore, the principles underpinning the university's founding include:<ref name=":1" /> * ''"that in determining the courses and programmes to be taught emphasis shall be placed on a balanced pursuit of the humanities, the basic sciences, the development, application and management of technology, which are of special relevance to the needs and aspirations of Ghanaians in particular, and others in general;'' * ''that higher education in this University shall be available to all Ghanaians and others who are capable of benefiting from it;'' * ''that research shall be undertaken in all courses which are taught in the University but with attention to courses which relate to the social, cultural, economic, scientific, technical and other problems which exists in Ghana or elsewhere in Africa;'' * ''that the fruits of research and knowledge generally shall be spread abroad by the publication of books and papers and by any other suitable means;'' * ''that students shall be taught methods of critical and independent thought, while being made aware that they have a responsibility to use their education for the service of the Church, country and humanity;'' * ''that as far as practicable the students shall be trained to be innovative and entrepreneurial to enhance socio- economic development;'' * ''that the University shall operationalize local, regional and global needs assessment as the basis for practical and multi-disciplinary outreach programmes in the local and regional communities;'' * ''that the University shall inculcate in the student ethical, moral and intellectual values that manifest in courage, discipline, fair play, self motivation and respect for the dignity of an honest life."''
==Organization== The university has four campuses at Abetifi-Kwahu, Akropong-Akuapem in the [[Eastern Region, Ghana|Eastern Region]], Asante Akyem-Agogo in the [[Ashanti Region]] and the city campus at Tema in the [[Greater Accra Region]]. Each of these campuses has its own set of faculties and other facilities.

Actuarial Science * BSc. Business Economics <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh/?q=node/12 |title=Tema Campus |accessdate=2015-01-22 |work=Official website |publisher=PUCG |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150122171139/http://www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh/?q=node%2F12 |archivedate=22 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Affiliations== The university is affiliated to the [[University of Ghana]] and [[Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ug.edu.gh/about/institutional-affiliations |title=Institutional Affiliations |accessdate=2016-11-25 |work=Official website |publisher=University of Ghana |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127172926/http://ug.edu.gh/about/institutional-affiliations |archivedate=27 November 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh/site/accreditation-and-affliation/ |title=Accreditation and affiliation |accessdate=2016-11-25 |year=2016 |work=Official website |publisher=Presbyterian University College |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161126065708/http://www.presbyuniversity.edu.gh/site/accreditation-and-affliation/ |archivedate=26 November 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
